data.title: Former N.W.A manager Jerry Heller, portrayed in Straight Outta Compton, dead at 75
data.meta_description: The music manager who helped introduce N.W.A to the masses has died. Jerry Heller was 75 years old.
data.text:
The music manager who helped introduce N.W.A to the masses has died. Jerry Heller was 75 years old.

Heller's cousin, Gary Ballen, says Heller died Friday night at a hospital in Thousand Oaks, Calif. after suffering a heart attack while driving earlier in the day.

Heller co-founded Ruthless Records with Eazy-E, which released N.W.A's seminal album Straight Outta Compton in 1988, launching the West Coast gangsta rap movement.

Ruthless was also behind such artists as J.J. Fad, Michel'le and Bone Thugs-N-Harmony.

Actor Paul Giamatti played Heller in last year's hit film Straight Outta Compton. Heller sued the film's producers for defamation after its release, claiming it portrayed him as a villain.

Controversial mogul

Heller was characterized in the film as someone who helped popularize N.W.A but later swindled and divided the group.

"It made him look bad, like he stole money from (Eazy) or something, which never happened," Ballen said Saturday about the 2015 movie. "They just rewrote history. And because of that, he had this lawsuit and it's been going on and on. It really stressed him out having to deal with all this stuff."

In June of 2016, a judge threw out most of Heller's law suit, but allowed one claim to continue.

Ballen said his cousin was "always kind of tormented" by his parting with Eazy and the label.

Born in Ohio, Heller started his career in the 1960s as an agent and promoter, working with such acts as Pink Floyd, Marvin Gaye and Creedence Clearwater Revival. He set up Elton John's first U.S. performance, Ballen said.

Heller released Ruthless: A Memoir in 2006.

Ballen remembered how excited Heller was to play him a cassette of N.W.A's early tracks.

'A real visionary'

"He said, 'You watch, this is going to be the biggest music ever. This is going to take over rock 'n' roll,'" Ballen recalled.

"Jerry was a real visionary ... As far as I'm concerned, there would never be a Dr. Dre or an Ice Cube if it wasn't for Jerry getting (N.W.A) their first deal, which was really difficult. Nobody wanted to sign them."

Heller had a history of heart problems and suffered from diabetes. Besides Ballen, Heller is survived by a brother and a nephew.
